results.title: La Gueule de L'autre = the Other One's Mug
results.brief_description:
Martial Perrin is campaigning for the country’s presidency at the helm of the Conservatist Independant and Progressist Party. After his campaign staff learns of an assasination plot, Martial is driven into hiding and ‘replaced’ by an ineffectual actor.

Credits: Producer, Georges Valon ; director, Pierre Tchernia ; writer, Jean Poiret ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Claude Bolling ; art direction, Willy Holt.
Cast: Michel Serrault, Jean Poiret, Andrea Parisy, Bernadette Lafont, Curd Jurgens, Francois Lalande, Dominique Lavanant, Hans Meyer, Georges Geret, Marco Perrin, Patrick Poivre d’Arvor.

results.title: La Guerre Est Finie = the War Is Over
results.creator_credit: Sofracima, Europa Films and Alain Resnais
results.brief_description:
Diego has spent his life working for a revolutionary group still fighting the battles of 1936 in a Spain that no longer exists. Living in Paris Diego makes repeated trips to Spain to work for the cause. Through his close collaboration with Jorge Semprun, the Spanish novelist then in exile, Resnais constructs the tragedy of a man who has come to question the very thing that has defined the value of his existence. He is bound to continue ‘the war’ but for him it is now more personal than political. Diego’s relationships with two women represent the myth and reality of his political life. The rhythms of the film are harnessed to Diego’s subjectivity - the memories, imaginings and connections in his mind together with moments of profound feeling. Also available on VHS (NLA #2081353).

Credits: Director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Jorge Semprun ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Giovanni Fusco ; editor, Eric Pluet.
Cast: Yves Montand, Ingrid Thulin, Genevieve Bujold, Jean Bouise, Antoine Vitez, Gerard Lartigau, Bernard Fresson.

results.title: La Guerre des Polices = the Police War
results.brief_description:
Fush and Ballestrat are rival police detectives who head different departments trying to capture a notorious gangster. Both are not above using underhanded and illegal means to attain their goals. To add to the tension between the two men, Marie, a female officer in Balestrat’s team is having an affair with Fush. During a stakeout gone wrong Fush must put his life on the line and confront his coveted prey: public ennemy number one, Sarlat. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesars) 1979: Best Actor for Claude Brasseur.

Credits: Producer, Vera Belmont ; director, Robin Davis ; writers, Robin Davis, Jean-Patrick Manchette, Jean-Marie Guillaume, Jacques Labib ; photography, Ramon Suarez ; music, Jean-Marie Senia.
Cast: Claude Brasseur, Marlene Jobert, Claude Rich, Jean-Francois Stevenin, Francois Perier, Etienne Chicot.

results.title: La Guerre des Boutons = War of the Buttons
results.brief_description:
Two rival gangs of small boys wage a daily battle in a sandpit between their two villages, taking prisoners whose belts, braces and buttons are cut off. Lebrac, leader of one gang, conceives the idea of surprising the other side by going into battle naked and chalks up a victory. As the war games become more elaborate, the parents have to intervene. The movie was a huge commercial success on initial release, but it is unlikely to appeal much to those more interested in the infinitely complex and unequivocally nasty ‘The Lord of the Flies’. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1962. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Yves Robert, Daniele Delorme ; director, Yves Robert ; writers, Yves Robert, Francois Boyer ; photography, Andre Bac ; music, Jose Berghams.
Cast: Andre Teton, Martin Lartigues, Michel Isella, Jacques Dufilho, Jean Richard, Michel Galabru, Paul Crauchet, Pierre Trabaud, Yvette Etievant, Robert Rollis.

results.title: La guerre de cent ans = The hundred year war
results.brief_description:
Episode 13 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Hundred Years’ War was an intermittent struggle between England and France in the 14th-15th century. The main reasons for disputes included the question of the legitimate succession to the French crown. The struggle involved several generations of English and French claimants to the crown and actually occupied a period of more than 100 years. By convention it is said to have started in 1337 and ended in 1453, but there had been periodic fighting over the question of English fiefs in France going back to the 12th century. Historians have long considered the Hundred Years’ War a milestone in the development of national consciousness in western Europe. The English, after their many successes and frustrations, were finally cured of their taste for continental intervention, and the English monarchs turned increasingly to the problems of internal development. The hard-fought success of the house of Valois in securing the French crown helped insure that France would not become a realm in name only, partitioned among numerous independent princes. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La Griffe et la Dent = Fang and Claw
results.creator_credit: Walter Spohr, Gerard Vienne and Francois Bel
results.brief_description:
Without narration, this wildlife documentary explores the behavior of African animals by day and by night, and is especially vivid in its depiction of the hunting behavior of large predators.

Credits: Producer, Walter Spohr ; directors, Gerard Vienne, Francois Bel ; music, Michel Fano.

results.title: La Grande Lessive! = The Big Wash!
results.brief_description:
Apalled to see how sleepy and apathetic his students have become, headmaster Saint-Just enrolls the help of a gym teacher and an inventor to sabotage all the TV antennas of Paris. The police is soon called to solve the mystery as the professor and his crew slowly move towards their ultimate goal of spraying the transmitter atop the Eiffel tower. Best print: X0109 ; 2nd best: X0032.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cheyko ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Jean-Pierre Mocky, Claude Pennec, Alain Moury ; photography, Marcel Weiss ; music, Francois de Roubaix ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Pierre Tyberghien.
Cast: Bourvil, Francis Blanche, Roland Dubillard, Jean Poiret, Jean Tissier, Michel Lonsdale, Karin Balm.

results.title: La Grande illusion = Grand illusion
results.creator_credit: Réalisation d'art cinématographique (R.A.C.) and Jean Renoir
results.brief_description:
During World War I, three French soldiers are captured behind enemy lines following an ill-fated air mission. They are taken as prisonners to a castle fortress, commanded by Von Rauffenstein. Capitaine de Boeldieu and Von Rauffenstein take an immediate liking to each other as members of the same aristocratic caste, while Lt. Marechal, a working-class mechanic and Rosenthal, a prosperous Jewish banker only dream of escape. In this war film without battle scenes, Renoir touches upon the futility of war and also suggests that the true source of human conflict may be found in class division rather than nationality, as symbolised by the relationship between Boeldieu and Rauffenstein as well as the blooming romance between Marechal and a young German widow (in spite of their not speaking the same language). ‘La Grande Illusion’ is often described as the greatest film about war ever made. The title is an ironic reference to the illusion entertained by many that The Great War would be the last one. To quote film critic Jonathan Rosenbaum, “the film doesn’t have quite the demonic, polyphonic, and emotionally contradictory brilliance of Renoir’s ‘The Rules of the Game’, made two years later, but it’s still one of the key humanist expressions to be found in movies: sad, funny, exalting, and glorious.” Also available on LD and VHS.

Credits: Director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Charles Spaak, Jean Renoir ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Joseph Kosma ; editor, Marguerite Huguet.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Pierre Fresnay, Erich von Stroheim, Julien Carette, Dita Parlo, Jacques Becker, Marcel Dalio.

results.title: La Gioconda
results.creator_credit: Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen, Filippo Sanjust and Hugo Kach
results.brief_description: Set in the 17th Century, a ballad singer attempts to save her mother and win the love of her Genoese Prince by becoming involved in the elopement of two lovers. Performers include: Eva Marton, Placido Domingo, Matteo Manuguerra, Ludmila Semtschuk, Kurt Rydl. Vienna State Opera (Vienna) conducted by Adam Fischer. Text by Arrigo Boito after Victor Hugo. Music by Amilcare Ponchielli.

results.title: La Garonne
results.brief_description: One of a series of teaching films with commentary in simple french. Sketches the outlines of france and the course of the river with its tributaries, before presenting its source in the Pyrenees whose peaks we see as we descend close to the torrent through gorges and ravines.
